But here it is 211, because of the special rounding convention that makes a 9, and a 10 and up become a 0 in front of the next digit. In other words, 210 is just the same number as 210.000, 210.0000000000000 and any other long series of zeros in the same place.

The initial answer (211) is one that fits with the other numbers (9, 62, 140) if the sum of the first two is smaller than the sum of the other two. (It would be 211 if the second number had been -62 instead.) In this way it is quite similar to the 21 mentioned above. # the answer from this post https://datascience.stackexchange.com/questions/10419/how-to-use-statistical-methods-for-calculating-accuracy-of-machine-learning-algori
```python
def get_confidence_interval(probs, confidence=0.95):
    # if you know the std value, you can calculate it more exactly
    # if not, the below can be an approximation
    # http://mathworld.wolfram.com/Studentt-Distribution.html
    n = probs.shape[0]
    margin = stats.t.interval(confidence, n-1)[1]
    interval = margin * np.sqrt((1./n + 1./(n-1))*probs*(1-probs))
    return interval
```
